Problem:
Consider a system modeled by a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i \\omega t} x_0 \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a constant and \\( x_0 \\) is the initial complex value. This system undergoes an integral transformation given by \\( T[f](x) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-2 \\pi i x t} f(t) dt \\), and we explore the influence of this transformation on the system's behavior.

Applying the transformation \\( T \\) to \\( z(t) \\) at time t = 0, then letting it evolve under the original system dynamics without any further transformation, will \\( z(T) \\) at T = t be affected by the initial transformation?
Explanation: The transformation \\( T \\) modifies \\( z(t) \\) into its Fourier transform, changing the state in a way that is not equivalent to the simple evolution under \\( e^{i \\omega t} x_0 \\). This new state evolves differently due to the alteration in its frequency components.
